talk.author: did:plc:d2txneimf647smkntm5c27fo
talk.utter: They also don’t understand what continuing positive rapids mean. I know a parent at our school—an otherwise intelligent person—who’s convinced herself that “dead proteins” (and not viral load) account for any positives after some unspecified point.

talk.author: did:plc:jsowo4x4dytbl5hpjbm4e3tt
talk.utter:
The dead proteins thing is true for PCR tests I think? PCR can detect previous infection for months (with increasing cycle counts).

But rapid tests work based on existent viral load, so if it’s positive it’s fucking positive.

The question has always been how to interpret a negative rapid test.

talk.author: did:plc:d2txneimf647smkntm5c27fo
talk.utter: Yeah, I suspect she’s confused the two.

talk.author: did:plc:d2txneimf647smkntm5c27fo
talk.utter:
There should be lots of ways for people to learn this. Schools. The media. Posters on transit. Radio announcements. 

So many balls dropped.

talk.author: did:plc:zhy73wow23zh5yzqcad72nzo
talk.utter:
Even if people get the basic understanding of airborne, infectiousness, how to prevent transmission it's still impossible to do personal risk assessments because there's no data to make an assessment.
Really need good PH comms for covid. Like we used to have here in 2020
#covid

talk.author: did:plc:d2txneimf647smkntm5c27fo
talk.utter: Wastewater reporting should be part of the nightly news, just like the weather. Air quality of indoor spaces should be posted, like they used to do with restaurant inspections.
